acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3 from its 72h-ErC50 = 33 mg/L for algae (Desmodesmus subspicatus) (SIDS, 2006).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, LD50 values are >1000 mg/kg and >250 mg/kg for rabbits (SIDS (access on April. 2009)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on a LC50 value of 104 ppm/4h for rats (ACGIH (2001)), the substance was classified into Category 4. Since the test was conducted at lower than 90% of saturated vapour pressure concentration, the classification criteria for gas was adopted.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on LD50 values of 18 mg/kg, 200 mg/kg and 550 mg/kg for rats (SIDS (access on April. 2009)), the lowest value (18 mg/kg) was adopted and the substance was classified into Category 2.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified since the toxicity is mitigated in environmental water by buffer action though it is considered to be a factor of toxicity that water solution becomes strongly acidic.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative results in a human peripheral lymphocyte chromosomal aberration test (in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity test) and a bone marrow micronucleus test by intraperitoneal administration to mice (in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity test) (SIDS (2009)), the substance was classified as "Not classified". As relevant information, from in vitro mutagenicity tests, there is a report of a negative Ames test (SIDS (2009)).

hazardous_to_ozone.rationale: This substance is not listed in Annexes to the Montreal Protocol.

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classification is not possible since no data are available though the substance contains chlorine.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: There is a report that skeletal development in treated fetuses was retarded but no other effects were observed in a rat oral test (organogenesis period: days 5 - 16 of pregnancy) (SIDS (2009)). Since there is no data for effects on sexual function and fertility, classification was not possible due to lack of sufficient data.

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: There is a report that symptoms included irritation of the pharynx and asthmatic bronchitis which occurred 1 to 8 weeks after exposure in workers employed in the production of the substance (ACGIH (2001)). In addition, although there are reports of an impairment of lung function and asthmatic bronchitis after inhalation exposure to humans (SIDS (2009)), these data are not sufficient as evidence of induction of specific respiratory hypersensitivity, therefore, classification was not possible due to lack of other data.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on results of "corrosive" in a rabbit test (SIDS (2009)) and "irreversible necrosis causing loss of vision" in a second rabbit test (SIDS (2009)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on results of "highly corrosive" following application for 60 seconds in a rabbit test (SIDS (2009)) and "irritating or corrosive" in a second rabbit test (SIDS (2009)), the substance was classified into Category 1A. As relevant information, the substance is classified into C; R35 in EU classification.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Classification is not possible since no data are available though the substance contains phosphorous. It is considered that the substance is outside of the range of combustible risk since it is not classified into Division 4.3 in UNRTDG though the information is available that the substance violently reacts with water "forming combustible phosphine together with the generation of heat which may spontaneously ignite and explode" (NFPA (13th, 2006), "forming combustible diphoshane" (Bretheric (7th, 2007)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Following repeated exposure the following symptoms were observed in exposed individuals: irritation of the pharynx, coughing and asthmatic bronchitis. These symptoms occurred 1 to 8-week after exposure. In workers who had at least 1 year of exposure, emphysema was sometimes found (ACGIH (2001)). After 4-week of inhalation exposure to rats, inflammation and squamous metaplasia of respiratory epithelium were observed at a concentration of 10 ppm/6h (0.0561mg/L/6h, 90-day equivalence: 0.019 mg/L/6h) which is within the guidance value range for Category 1 (SIDS (access on Apr. 2009)). Based on these reports, the substance was classified into Category 1 (respiratory system).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: The symptoms in 23 workers following inhalation exposure of the substance (1.8 - 27 ppm) included burning eyes and throat, irritation of pharyngeal mucous membranes, and mild bronchitis. These changes occurred within 2 to 6-hour following exposure (ACGIH (2001)). In a spill incident during a filling operation, 17 exposed individuals experienced dyspnea, vomiting and decrements in vital capacity (ACGIH (2001)). Based on these reports, the substance was classified into Category 1 (respiratory system).
